conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The objects are placed on a flat surface (the slabs), and the light source is at a certain height above these objects.
When the light source moves forward, it changes its position relative to the objects and the ground.
The angle at which the light rays hit the objects and the ground will change.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift in the direction opposite to the movement of the light source.
The light rays that form the shadows will now be coming from a different angle, causing the shadows to move backward.
When the light source moves forward, the angle of the light rays becomes more oblique relative to the ground.
This oblique angle causes the shadows to stretch out, making them larger.
The closer the light source is to the objects (in terms of horizontal distance), the more pronounced the effect of shadow enlargement will be.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward and become larger.
